fax: +98 451 5514701 Here, we developed a copper oxide based photocatalyst for the reducing nitrobenzenes to the aminobenzenes using hydrazine monohydrate in the presence of visible light. Reduction of a mixture of Cu (II) and graphene oxide (GO) with NaBH4.H2O leads to the formation of a photocatalyst (rGO/Cu2O-CuO) in which reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets coupled with Cu2O and CuO nanoparticles. The prepared photocatalyst and its photoactivity were identified and studied using FTIR, Raman, XRD, XPS, FESEM, TEM, EDAX, DRS, BET, EIS and PL technique. The catalyst is used for the reduction of nitrobenzenes to corresponding aminobenzenes by use of hydrazine monohydrate under the 30 W visible light radiation. The photocatalyst was recovered and reused seven times and no significant change in efficiency was observed. 1 Introduction Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key words Cu2O CuO photocatalyst rGO visible light reduction nitrobenzene In recent years, photocatalytic reactions have attracted considerable attention due to their many applications. Purification and degradation of toxic pollutants in water and industrial effluents, organic synthesis, hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity of surfaces, production of self-cleaning surfaces and electrolysis of water for hydrogen production are among the important applications of photocatalysts [1–4]. Researchers are always looking for photocatalysts with high activity and efficiency, high selectivity and high capability of recovery from the reaction mixture [5]. At the present moment, the development of green and sustainable methods for organic evolution has become a major requirement in chemistry. Among the known approaches, light-based reactions are especially important due to the cheapness, natural abundance and availability of light [6–8]. Apart from the degradation of organic pollutants and domestic wastewater treatment [9], the development of chemical photocatalytic transformations has attracted much attention in recent years and is currently growing rapidly around the world [10–12]. Nitroaromatic compounds are widely used as the most important natural compounds and active ingredients in the main structure of dyes, stabilizers and polymerization inhibitors [13, 14]. In addition, nitroaromatic compounds (NAC) are widely used in pesticides, explosives, by-products in the extraction of hydrocarbon resources (oil and gas), etc. Since these compounds are water-soluble, they pollute the environment and surface and groundwater. The rapid and easy reduction of nitroaromatic compounds is a desirable option due to the increased biodegradability of the resulting products [15–20]. However, the anaerobic reduction process is usually slow and therefore valuable for improving removal performance [21, 22]. On the other hand, the reduction of nitro compounds to the corresponding amines is done due to the pharmacological importance of these compounds which are intermediates in the synthesis of various bioactive compounds [23–25]. For example, reduction of nitrobenzenes leads to the formation of aminobenzenes, which are significant intermediates for the synthesis of a variety of dyes and chemical indicators, drugs, agricultural pesticides, animal supplements and medicines, coatings, makeup materials and chemicals [26]. Visible-light active semiconductors have an important role in the elimination of environmental pollutants and are of great interest due to their strong oxidation and reduction ability, low cost, performance at ambient temperature, and environmental friendliness [27–29]. Among them, copper oxides, which are considered as semiconductors can absorb the most of visible light, are more important due to their abundance, cheapness, low harmfulness and ease of synthesis, compared to other semiconductors. Due to the prevention of reverse electron transfer in photocatalytic reactions and increased photocatalytic activity, copper oxides have significantly been considered in the preparation of sensors [30], cells photovoltaic solar [31], lithium ion batteries [32] and analytical devices [33], and increase their performance. To improve the photocatalytic activity of various semiconductors, graphene oxide sheets have been extensively studied as acceptors and transmitters of electrons produced under visible light to prevent electron and hole recombination [34–36]. Recently, numerous studies have shown that the electrons produced in graphene oxide-coupled semiconductor composites are transported by graphene oxide to participate in optical reactions [36–39]. This can improve the photocatalytic performance in terms of increasing the absorption of pollutants, increasing the amplitude of light absorption and increasing the charge separation compared to pure metal oxides and other nanoparticles [40, 41]. Despite numerous published reports on the photocatalytic activity of Cu2O [42, 43] and CuO [44] semiconductors, the use of both semiconductors in the composition of photocatalyst has been of great interest to researchers [45, 46]. As mentioned above, the use of multicomponent nanoparticles improve the efficiency and increase the photocatalytic activity [47]. In this research work, rGO/Cu2O-CuO was prepared as a new composition, characterized and used as a photocatalyst for the reduction of some nitrobenzenes under the visible light radiation (Figure 1). 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals and solvents were purchased from Merck and Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of graphene oxide (GO) As an approved method, modified Hummer strategy was used to prepare graphene oxide. In a 500 mL balloon, 3.0 g of powdered graphite and 100 mL of 98% concentrated sulfuric acid were magnetic stirred at 25°C for 10 minutes. The suspension was cooled to 0-5°C in an ice both. Then 3.0 g of sodium nitrate was added and stirred for 1 hour. To the above stirring mixture, 11.0 g of KMnO4 was gradually added over 2 hours (during this time the temperature should be below 10°C). Then the temperature was raised to 40°C and further stirred for another 2 hours. After adding 70 mL of distilled water, the mixture was stirred for another 30 minutes at 90°C. 25 mL of hydrogen peroxide solution (30%) and 230 mL distilled water were carefully poured into the above mixture and then stirred for 30 minutes. The result was subjected to sonication for 40 minutes, centrifuged, washed with HCl solution (5%) and then fully dried for 24 hours at 70°C in an oven. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Cu2O nanoparticles A solution of 0.02 mol (4.00 g) of copper (II) acetate monohydrate in 40 mL distilled water was prepared. Another solution was prepared by dissolving 0.02 mol (0.80 g) of sodium hydroxide in 10 mL distilled water, then the two solutions were mixed together. As a result of mixing, an aqueous solution of Cu(OH)2 was formed. In the next step, 10 mL of aqueous solution of ascorbic acid (0.2 mol/L) was added dropwise to the above Cu(OH)2 solution. In a few minutes, the blue solution becomes colorless and then red, indicating the formation of a Cu2O precipitate. Washing the resulting precipitate with water and then drying at 80°C, will give Cu2O powder. 2.2.3 Synthesis of CuO nanoparticles Cu(NO3)2.3H2O (12.08g) was dissolved in deionized water (80 mL) in an Erlenmeyer flask. The Erlenmeyer was sonicated for 60 minutes by use of an ultrasonic unit at 25°C. The content of Erlenmeyer flask was poured into a 100 mL Teflon lined autoclave. It was sealed and heated at 180°C for 12 hours and then slowly cooled to 25°C. The solid product was centrifuged, washed for several times with water and ethanol, and finally dried at 70°C for 12 hours in an oven. Scheme 1. 2.2.4 Synthesis of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-x Reduction of a mixture of GO and Cu (II) with NaBH4 led to the synthesis of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-x nanocomposites. For this aim, 50 mg of graphene oxide was subjected to sonication in 50 mL of DI water for 1 hour and then 10 mL of the certain concentrations of Cu (II) solutions was added to the mixture. In the following, aqueous solution of NaBH4 (10 mL, 0.2 M) was poured dropwise to the above mixture. The mixture was magnetic stirred for 45 minutes. Then, the resulting mixture was poured into a Teflon lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 hours. The autoclave was cooled to 25°C and the precipitate obtained was washed with DI water for several times and then separated by centrifugation and fully dried at 70°C for 24 hours. For the preparing of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-1, rGO/Cu2O-CuO-2, rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3, rGO/Cu2O-CuO-4 and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-5 nanocomposites, 1.79, 3.67, 7.75, 12.31 and 17.44 mg of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O (in 10 mL DI water) were used respectively in above procedure. 2.3 Instruments Identification of the products and determination of the reaction conversion were performed by use of a flame ionization detector Agilent 7890A GC (gas chromatography). The temperature program of the column was set between 180 and 220°C at an increasing rate of 2°C/min. The carrier gas was nitrogen with the flow rate of 20 ml/min. FTIR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer. Takram P50C0R10 instrument was used to record Raman spectra of the samples. Crystalline structure of samples was studied with a Philips X'pert instrument (Cu-Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å) at the angle range of 10° < 2θ < 80° with the scan rate of 5 °/min. Recording of X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS analysis)was done with Thermo Fischer ESCALAB 250Xi. To achieve core level spectra, pass energy was 10 eV with selected steps equal to 0.02 eV. The morphological structure and size of rGO/Cu2O-CuO nanocomposites were specified by field emission scanning electron microscope (MIRA3TESCAN-XMU) which has an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) microanalysis for quantitative measurement of elements of nanoparticles. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of rGO/Cu2O-CuO nanoparticles was conducted by use of FEI Tecani G2-20 TWIN microscope (at 200 kV). To carry out the analysis, the nanoparticles (rGO/Cu2O-CuO) were spread out on a thin layer of carbon with a diameter of 3 mm placed on a copper grid. The characterization of optical properties of the photocatalyst (rGO/Cu2O-CuO) was conducted by UV/Vis spectrophotometer with diffuse reflectance accessory (DRS); the BaSO4 was the internal reflectance standard. The optical band gap energy of nanocomposites was obtained by UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectrophotometer (DRS) (Sinco S4100, Korea). The results of the DRS were converted to the Tauc equation. The optical band gap of nanocomposites is calculated by Tauc formula. α h υ · = · A ( h υ · − · E g ) n n refers to the index which depends on the type of transition and may have values. Measurements of pore size distributions and surface area of the nanocomposite was carried out by the BET N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, as shown in figure 8. On the base of obtained isotherms, the measured surface area of the rGO/Cu2O-CuO photocatalyst was 51.6940 m2 g−1. Measurements of electrochemical impedance were conducted by use of a μ‐Autolab 3 galvanostat/potentiostat (Metrohm). The potential of the electrode was set to 0.17 V relative to SCE; the amplitude of AC voltage used was 0.05 V and the frequency range applied was 0.1–100000 Hz. A typical three‐electrode system consisting of a standard calomel reference electrode (SCE), a counter electrode (a small platinum rod), and a working electrode (rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 that has modified indium tin oxide) was used. The electrolytic cell consists of a container in which 5 mM K3Fe(CN)6/K4Fe(CN)6 dissolved in 0.1 M KCl solution of electrolyte. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the photocatalysts FTIR spectra of samples (GO, rGO, CuO, Cu2O and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3) are show in Figure 1. The vibration bands at 1056, 1216, 1380, 1602, 1710 and 3412 cm−1 are attributed to C-O-C, C-O, C-C, C=C, C=O and O-H [48, 49]. The disappearane of C=O peak at 1710 cm−1 in rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 is related to the reduction of GO to rGO [50]. The two peaks appeared at 620 and 512 cm−1 are related to Cu-O bond vibration of Cu2O and CuO nanoparticles on the rGO [46, 51]. Raman data were used to better understand the existence of appropriate interactions between rGO and nanoparticles. Figure 2 illustrates the Raman spectroscopy investigations of GO, rGO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3. In Figure 2, D and G bands related to sp2 and sp3 hybridized atoms of samples, are considered. In the GO, rGO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 spectra, the D and G bands appear at 1356 and 1603 cm−1 [52]. The 2D graphene oxide band is also seen at 2940 cm−1. The peaks at 89.9 and 681 cm−1 are assigned to Cu2O and CuO, respectively. Typically, the ID/IG ratio was used to measure the relative concentration of SP3 defects relative to SP2 hybridization in graphene domain [53, 54]. In the present project, the ratio of ID/IG calculated for GO, rGO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 was equal to 0.892, 1.039 and 1.142, respectively. As the ratio (ID/IG) increases in rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3, the Cu2O and the CuO in the rGO layers have a high level of structural distortion confirming the successful formation of rGO/Cu2O-CuO [28, 52, 55, 56]. Figure 3 shows the XRD pattern of samples (Cu2O, CuO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 nanoparticles). The pattern of Cu2O can be considered as (110), (111), (200), (220) and (311) sheets with cubic structure as explained in JCPDS card No. 01-078-2076. The XRD pattern for CuO corresponds to the (110), (11-1), (111), (20-2), (020), (202), (11-3), (31-1) and (220) orientations with monoclinic morphology as described in JCPDS card No. 48-1548 [45,57,58]. As seen in on XRD pattern of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 nanocomposites, it is quite clear that both of copper oxides (Cu2O and CuO) were formed in the rGO layers. The deconvoluted XPS spectra of Cu2p, C1s and O1s XPS of the rGO/Cu2O-CuO nanocomposite were presented in Figure 4 . In Figure 4a, the peaks at 932.5, 934.6, 952.6 and 954.6 eV are respectively related to the peaks of Cu+2p3/2, Cu2+2p3/2, Cu+2p1/2 and Cu2+2p1/2, which indicates the presence of Cu2O and CuO in the nanocomposite [59,60]. Based on the analysis of XPS spectrum and measurement of the peaks area, the atomic ratio of Cu2+/Cu+ in the nanocomposite was calculated approximately equal to 2.02. The deconvoluted spectrum of C1s in Figure 4b, shows three distinct peaks at 284.6, 286.6 and 283.3 eV relating to C-C, C-O and C=O. Four peaks were identified after deconvolution of the O1s XPS spectrum (Figure 4b). The two peaks at ∼532 and 533.3 eV belong to the C=O and OH located in the surface of rGO sheets and other two peaks at 530.0 eV and 531.4 eV identified are related to the lattice oxygens in CuO and Cu2O [59, 61]. Investigation of FESEM and TEM images reveals how the copper oxide nanoparticles are distributed on rGO sheets (Figure 5 ). A closer look at TEM images reveals that copper oxide has successfully been created on rGO nanolayers. Figure 6 shows the EDAX spectrum and elemental mapping of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3. It shows the almost uniform distribution of the related elements (C, O and Cu) on the surface of prepared photocatalyst. This uniformity indicates that Cu2O and CuO have been effectively coupled on the rGO sheets. To study the photoactivity, the Tauc diagrams and DRS spectra of Cu2O, CuO, GO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 were obtained (Figure 7 ). As mentioned in some reports, the maximum adsorption intensities of Cu2O and CuO are obtained at 636 and 730 nm [44, 62]. Samples band gaps were obtained using the Tauc formula. The Eg values for Cu2O, CuO, GO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 were obtained 2.00, 1.77, 2.73 and1.74 eV, respectively. Nitrogen adsorption desorption isotherms for Cu2O, CuO, GO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3, at different relative pressures, are shown in Figure 8 . It is obvious that these samples, based on IUPAC, are of type-IV isotherm with a detectable hysterical ring, indicating the existence of capillary holes formed by accumulation of sheets and particles [10, 62, 63]. In Cu2O, CuO, GO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3, the contact surfaces (BET method) were respectively calculated as 9.9779, 4.9902, 10.444 and 51.6940 cm3g−1, as shown in Table 1 . These data indicate that the interactive surface of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 is more than that of Cu2O, CuO and GO. For the approving of photocatalytic reactions, the photocurrent analysis of Cu2O, CuO, GO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 was performed. By considering in Figure 9 a, the photocurrent intensity of the rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 is greater than the Cu2O, CuO, GO samples. The obtained results of the photocurrent confirmed that the effective separation of charge carriers play a critical role in the increasing photocatalytic activity of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results of the samples (Cu2O, CuO, GO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3) were shown in Figure 9b. ESI is a powerful method to evaluate the increase in photocatalytic activity based on the rate of improvement of charge separation efficiency. The semicircle of the Nyquist diagram of EIS corresponds to electron transfer limit and the diameter of that is equivalent to the charge transfer resistance (RCT) [64]. As the diameter decreaces in rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 compared to Cu2O, CuO and GO, the charge transfer increases. Figure 9c shows the photoluminescence (PL) spectra of the samples (Cu2O, CuO, GO, and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3) at 25°C at 350 nm excitation wavelength. The spectra show a wide emission in the visible region (400-700 nm) which is related to photoluminescence from the ground state to the level in which electron-holes recombination. So the bands at 417 and 454 nm in the spectra are related to crystal defects introduced during the growth of the nanoparticles and intrinsic defects or surface states [65, 66]. As seen in the case of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3, the emission intensity significantly decreases and becomes comparable to each of Cu2O, CuO and GO. Decrease in peak intensity in rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 shows a synergistic effect occurs between different components of the photocatalyst which reduces electron and holes recombination rate. Mott–Schottky analysis was used to determine the donor density (VB) of Cu2O and CuO. Both Cu2O and CuO show a negative slope which indicates p-type semiconductor properties (Figure 9 d). The VB potentials of Cu2O and CuO were obtained +0.6 and +0.71 V vs. Ag/AgCl respectively from the x interception of the linear region. Finally the obtained potentials vs. Ag/AgCl were converted into normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) by using the E(vs. NHE)= E(vs. Ag/AgCl)+EAgCl+(0.059 × pH). By placing the pH=6.9 (pH of measured electrolyte), EAgCl= 0.197 V and +0.6 (for Cu2O) and +0.71 V vs. Ag/AgCl (for CuO) in the mentioned equation, the values 1.23 eV and 1.3 eV were obtained for VB of Cu2O and CuO respectively. Finally, by considering the values of Eg (Figure 7) and obtained VB, the CB's were obtained -0.74 eV and -0.47 eV for Cu2O and CuO respectively which are in good agreement with the literature [67]. 3.2 Photocatalytic activity Photocatalytic reduction of nitroaromatic compounds was carried out under the influence of visible light radiation by use of a white LED lamp (30 watt, λ> 420 nm). For this aim, 50 mg of photocatalyst was dispersed for 45 minutes in a test tube containing 10 mL of a mixture of three solvents including methanol, acetonitrile and dichloromethane in a ratio of 1:1:1 by an ultrasonic bath. Then 1 mmol of nitrobenzene and 5 mmol of hydrazine (H2N4.H2O) were added to the stirring suspension. Then the result, while being stirred, was exposed to irradiation of visible light for various time durations. The optimal reaction time was determined by GC/MS analysis of the reaction products. At the end, the photocatalyst was separated by filtration and the product was identified using GC/MS. So in a typical procedure, one of GO, rGO, Cu2O, CuO and rGO/Cu2O-CuO-x (x=1-5) was used as a photocatalyst for the reduction of nitrobenzene with hydrazine monohydrate (NH2NH2.H2O) under the influence of visible light irradiation. The optimum condition for nitrobenzene reduction in the presence of photocatalysts is given in Table 2 . As shown in entries 1-4, the reaction conversion of nitrobenzene reduction in the presence of GO, rGO, Cu2O and CuO, as photocatalyst, was obtained 20, 26, 40 and 27 percent respectively in 12 hours. With reconsidering in the results obtained in the Table 2 (entries 5, 6), it seemed that rGO plays an important role in the photocatalytic reduction process and the photocatalytic reduction conversion increased to 78 and 69 respectively. In continuous, the conversion percentage of nitrobenzene reduction reaction for rGO/Cu2O-CuO-x in the presence of visible light are also presented in entries 7-11. The higher concentration of the Cu2O-CuO on the rGO support affected the reaction adversely. Investigation of the role of solvent is one of the important issues in photocatalytic processes [68]. The photoreduction reaction of nitrobenzene carried out in methanol alone (80%), acetonitrile alone (86%) and dichloromethane alone (83%). In the heterogeneous catalysts, the dispersion of catalyst and solubility of the substrates can be affected by the kind of reaction solvents. In this research work, it seems that methanol and acetonitrile can disperse the catalyst in the reaction media and dichloromethane can be beneficial for better dissolving of substrate. However, the mixing of ternary solvent system (methanol, dichloromethane and acetonitrile) provided better homogenous medium along with better solubility of the substrates and good dispersion of the photocatalyst for the reaction. Conversion percentage of nitrobenzene photoreduction reaction for rGO/Cu2O-CuO-x (x = 1-5) in the mixture of methanol, dichloromethane and acetonitrile (1:1:1) were obtained 71, 78, 100, 84 and 78 percent during two hours, respectively. To better clarify the role of visible light and photocatalyst, the reduction was performed in the presence of a reducing agent (NH2NH2.H2O) and photocatalyst in darkness; as shown in Table 2 (entry 12), the degree of conversion was achieved equal to 23% after 2 hours. In the other test, the reduction was performed in the presence of a reducing agent (hydrazine monohydrate) and visible light radiation without photocatalyst. The conversion percentage was obtained 14% (Table 2, entry 13). The progress of reaction and determination of products were detected using gas chromatography-mass spectroscopy (Figure 10 ). For further evaluation, our research team performed tests to reduce other nitroaromatic compounds. In a typical experiment, 1 mmol nitroaromatic compound was reduced with 5 mmol hydrazine monohydrate in 10 mL of a mixture of methanol, dichloromethane and acetonitrile (1:1:1) under visible light (30 watt white LED lamp) in the presence of 50 mg rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 at room temperature (Table 3 ). Analysis of the results shows that the degree of reaction conversion depends not only on the position but also on the nature of the functional groups placed on nitrobenzene ring. In fact, the functional groups affect the degree of reaction conversion based on their electronic properties (resonance and induction effects). Therefore, the reduction reaction of various nitrobenzenes, which include electron-withdrawing groups such as m-OH, NO2, and halides, takes less reaction time, and the same reaction in the presence of electron-donating groups such as p-OH, p-, m-NH2, and CH3 takes relatively more time. It should be noted that as can be deduced from the values of Hammett substituent constants (δm is 0.121 and -0.16 for OH and NH2, respectively, which is in fact the result of the sum of inductive, resonance, and steric effects), the hydroxyl and amino groups in the ortho position behave as electron-withdrawing and electron donor groups, respectively. For OH and NH2, the value of δp is -0.37 and -0.66, which shows that these groups, in para position, act as electron-withdrawing groups [69]. The recyclability of the catalyst was examined for the seven times; no significant change was observed in the degree of reaction conversion (Figure 11 ). To do this, the photocatalyst was recovered by centrifugation, then fully washed with absolute ethanol. After drying at 60°C for 6 hours, it was used in a new reaction. 3.3 Reduction reaction mechanism of nitroaromatic compounds In Figure 12 , a mechanism is proposed for the reduction of the nitro group to the amino group in the presence of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 as a photocatalyst. When Cu2O and CuO (Eg=2.00 and 1.77 eV, respectively) are exposed to light, they are excited and generate electron-hole pairs. So the transfer of excited electrons takes place from conduction band of Cu2O to that of CuO. In the mixture of rGO, Cu2O and CuO, the rGO acting as an electron sink, prevents the recombination of electron-holes, increases the life of the charge carrier, enhances the charge separation process and thus significantly improves the charge separation. Therefore, electrons produced by light are readily available to reduce nitroaromatics to the corresponding amines. However, hydrazine is oxidized by holes created in the Cu2O and CuO valence bands (in rGO/Cu2O-CuO). Hydrazine actually acts as an electron donor and hydrogen supplier in this reaction. According to the available researches and articles, the reduction mechanism of nitroaromatic compounds to the aminoaromatics is not precisely known. Two general paths can be proposed for reduction of nitrobenzene to aniline. The first path goes through the formation of nitrosobenzene and N-phenylhydroxylamine as intermediates (direct pathway), while the second path involves a condensation reaction in which azobenzene, azoxybenzene and hydrazobenzene are formed as probable intermediates [15]. To further evaluate the reaction mechanism, the reaction intermediates, at the beginning of the reaction, were investigated by use of GC-MS; nitrosobenzene was determined as the intermediate of the reaction (Figure 12b). In addition, no trace of azoxybenzene, azobenzene and hydrazobenzene was observed during the analysis. According to the above studies, the reaction mechanism is actually a direct path. Eventually, we compared and contrasted the results of our photocatalytic reduction reaction with the other reported results. As shown in the Table 4 , our reaction shows better results in reducing nitrobenzenes than other similar reactions [15, 16, 18, 70]. For example, the degree of conversion of nitronenzene reduction to aminobenzene in the presence of our prepared photocatalyst (rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3) is approximately equal to 100% in 2 hours, but this value is equal to, 95.0 (in 6 hours), 88.0 (in 8 hours), 96.5 (in 8 hours), 97.2% (in 8 hours), 99 (in 10 hours) and 92 (in 35 hours) for Au2.6Cu0.4@ZrO2 [18], rGO/Fe(bpy)3 2+[12], Ni/g-C3N4 [70], rGO/NiO [15], rGO-Co30Pd70 [20] and GO/Au NPs [19] respectively. 4 Conclusion In the present research work, Cu2O and CuO nanoparticles were successfully synthesized and decorated between the layers of rGO. The prepared nanocomposite (rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3) was studied and identified with physical and chemical techniques including FTIR, Raman, XRD, XPS, FESEM, TEM, EDAX, DRS, BET, EIS and PL. Our research showed that rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 has a great potential for reduction of nitrobenzenes to the corresponding anilines in the presence of visible light radiation. The photocatalysts of this investigation offer a novel approach to carbon-based photocatalysts to decrease environmental pollution. The photocatalyst was recovered and reused seven times; no significant changes in photocatalytic activity were observed. The use of rGO/Cu2O-CuO-3 as a photocatalyst is a promising method to reduce nitroaromatic compounds and other environmental pollutants. coredata.dc:description: Here, we developed a copper oxide based photocatalyst for the reducing nitrobenzenes to the aminobenzenes using hydrazine monohydrate in the presence of visible light. Reduction of a mixture of Cu (II) and graphene oxide (GO) with NaBH4.H2O leads to the formation of a photocatalyst (rGO/Cu2O-CuO) in which reduced graphene oxide (rGO) sheets coupled with Cu2O and CuO nanoparticles. The prepared photocatalyst and its photoactivity were identified and studied using FTIR, Raman, XRD, XPS, FESEM, TEM, EDAX, DRS, BET, EIS and PL technique. The catalyst is used for the reduction of nitrobenzenes to corresponding aminobenzenes by use of hydrazine monohydrate under the 30 W visible light radiation. The photocatalyst was recovered and reused seven times and no significant change in efficiency was observed. 1 Introduction
coredata.dc:title: RGO/Cu2O-CuO nanocomposite as a visible-light assisted photocatalyst for reduction of organic nitro groups to amines
